number of helpful: 433 of 459 people (94%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
27, 2014
												As a projectile fighting game Lethal Leagues core is simple: hit your opponent with a ball to score and ultimately win a match.You can try a bare bones prototype on reptile games' website to see if you like that concept.Like many other recent small competitive games this one challenges the player with high risk&reward as a single hit from the ball is a knock out. Although if you or your team hit the ball last it won't harm you.The intense fun of this game starts to kick in once you've hit the ball back and forth a few times, ever increasing its speed to ridiculously high levels (speedometer at the bottom on the boombox). Normal hits only increase the ball speed by 1, charged hits and smashes however double the speed. With more speed the hit lag will increase, the screen will shake, the background will change, intense visual effects will ripple across the screen and the characters will throw catchy phrases at each other as they hit the ball. Next to jumping and swinging you can also bunt the ball to slightly decrease the speed and carefuly set up your next attack.The movement mechanics are very solid. You can move right and left as you jump, you can tap for a short hop or hold to jump higher and stay in the air longer as well as press down to fall faster.The selectable characters two major mechanic differences are their method of gaining height (high jump, wall jump, double jump, wall ride, ...) and their special move, which can be activated with a full special bar (builds up by hitting the ball).Next to online and local multiplayer with up to 4 people there is also a single player challenge with 10 increasingly difficult stages to beat in sequence and in local multiplayer there are 7 levels of AI difficulty with the highest one still being a challenge even if you are already very good at the game - although not as engaging as a good human player will probably be.And it's a damn lot of fun.Raced to the top of my most played game ever list during beta testing.

r 18, 2014
												As a big fan of local multiplayer games, I originally got this thinking it'd be a fun couple hours of casual fighting with a group of friends. While it was certainly that, I never expected to get so deep into (what I deemed as) a "party game."The online community is fantastically rich- Just hop in the group chat, and you're bound to find a match with someone of whatever skill you're looking for, or someone to help practice a specific tactic, or just some casual FFA fun. There are tournaments hosted every weekend, and virtually everyone in the community is a blast to talk to.But the game itself has a depth I have never seen before- I have over 100 hours logged of high-skill matches and tournaments, and I am still finding new strategies and mechanics to use. My current repertoire is even missing two mechanics that I know, and with those two, there are plenty of uses I haven't even thought of.The depth is incredible. The community is great. The style is fantastic, and the play is like nothing I've seen before. Buy the game- You won't be disappointed.

content:
29, 2014
												The online is incredibly good, which is to be expected from GGPO.  4 player games tend to lag/desync a bit, but as long as you are not playing across countries, it handles it well.  1v1 online is nearly perfect from my viewpoint.Controller support is also good, I have tested 4 different controllers, all of which worked.  Only a few required minimal key binding.Gameplay itself is of the "simple to pick up, hard to master" variety.  Great for local party/competitive play.  Its fast paced, and has a lot of "epic moments" for all your friends to hype about.Not much content to be honest, though the game is obviously about multiplayer, and they do have a few modifiers to change things up.  But this is an important note, if you don't have good internet/local friends, do not get this game.  Though I doubt anyone reading this falls under this category.I personally like the art style, I have heard a lot of people complain about graphics.  I don't really need to review this though, if it looks ugly in the screenshots, you will find it ugly in game.Boss soundtrack, as in GOOD electronic music, not try hard dubstep.If my review seems badly written, it is because I am not a writer.  But you can trust me on this, Lethal League is amazing for what it is, and is definitly worth the asking price.  Anyone who is shying away because it is "too simple", there is a lot of depth/mind games to be had in hitting a ball back and forth(as silly as that sounds).  Is it another Nidhogg?  No.  Another Divekick?  ehhh, maybe, depends on whether you hated Divekick for its gameplay or for other reasons.  To me, this seems like a similar concept to Divekick, though better polished, different gameplay mechanic that is more hype because of its faster/more deep nature, and a better presentation.  This game is definitly better than Divekick, but still holds the similar concept of simple but hard to master.In the end, yes, I do recommend this game.  This game will entertain you and your friends for a long time.If I have not answered your questions/concerns about this game, leave a comment and I will edit the review."I am terrible at this game.10/10  Would noob rage again."Edit: Nominated for The “I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award” Award.

content:
14, 2015
												Lethal League is a 2D fighting game, but unlike traditional fighting games you don’t use fists or kicks or any kind of combat moves. You pick a character and hit an anti-gravity ball against your opponents to beat them, the ball speeds up and bounces harder off the walls with every hit it takes, reaching unbelievably fast speeds - particularly when one charges the hit. All this makes it hard to avoid the ball and also hard to hit the ball. Each player has a certain amount of lives per round and lose them by getting hit with the ball. Once all your lives run out you’re done, and the round ends when there’s only one player left in the game.Pros: ++++ The game is good fast-paced fun, the latency is very comfortable.+++ The audio and visual aspects are very befitting of each other, especially the effects and art style.+++ Music is awesome, fits perfectly with the battle atmosphere.++++ Hitting the ball feels solid, firm – making for immersive projectile battles.++ Different modes: FFA, TEAM DEATHMATCH+++ Different characters make for different moves/special moves.+++++ ”No weak ♥♥♥♥.”Bittersweet:-/+ Gameplay is easy to learn but hard to get good at, practice makes perfect and provides hours of fun.-/+ Speed cap for the ball is ridiculously high, might as well be infinite which makes for difficult but impressive moments.-/+ Limited player choice, however they are very stylish and have different colour schemes.-/+ Player base has cool people, but it’s not very big.Cons:-Not really anything negative about the game, if I had to name something it would be the lack of characters and small community.Final Opinion:All in all this game is addictive, exhilarating and a massive amount of fun. It’s as if Super Smash Bros, Pong, and whichever traditional 2D fighting game you can think of had a baby. Easy to pick up, hard to master. Art style, music and gameplay go perfectly well together for an amazing fighting experience.Liked this review? Join my group and follow my curator page.

content:
ber 2, 2014
												This game is the perfect example of how you simplify a fighting game to its roots while maintaining all the depth and metagame intact. Lethal League is a 3 button game (Hit, jump, stall/counter) where your goal is to hit your opponent with a ball, the ball builds speed with each hit and you have to be in the proper position to hit it back to your opponent while trying to not get hit by it.There's a limited roster of characters but all of them are very unique, no character plays exactly the same which makes every matchup very fun.This game also has a superb sountrack and an amazing netcode (GGPO) with up to 4 player online multiplayer.This is one of the most fun games i've played in a really long time, however there is a huge con to all of this, the game's asking price is $13.99 USD...Sure, that isn't much, right? it's the price of "X" or "Y" so it's not a big deal yadda yadda. However the game is truly lacking on the SP content, there's only a mode where you play against the CPU and a pretty barebones "Challenge mode" (Arcade mode) so there really isn't much outside of playing it against other people and even thought that's the main point of fighting games there's so many other games (Skullgirls, KOF) that at least cover a bare minimum of a Story Mode and a proper Arcade mode while also having very good tutorials (Skullgirls) and really good challenge modes (KOF Trials) both which have been in multiple sales for less than half the price of this game.The game is virtually dead on arrival, very much like Divekick (Even though Lethal League is incredibly better on every single aspect). It's almost impossible to find an online match because no one really is playing it and the price tag does not help the situation and it's a HUGE shame, because this could've been a smash hit that everyone would be talking about.Bottom line, this is one of the best fighting games you could ever play if you're either a veteran or a beginner, but i can't recommend this to everybody because the current price tag is not really justified, wait for a sale and buy it, maybe then more people will be playing it after they discover how amazing this game is.

number of helpful: 44 of 56 people (79%) found this review helpful5 people found this review funny
content:
10, 2015
												Video Review:


YouTube™ Video: Lethal League Review 

			Views: 1,134		

			Episode 48 - Lethally addicting Review by 16-Bit In today's episode we take a look at Lethal League! Make sure to check out written reviews and plenty of other well done reviews and recommended games...		

HISTORYReleased in August 2014 and developed by Team Reptile and based off the flash game prototype bearing the same name, it’s Lethal League!As of this review the game is on version 1.07.12STORY AND WHAT YOU DOIn Lethal League with no real context or story, you play as up to 6 different playable characters who face off against each other in an arena in up 4 players at once, the goal simply being to hit the ball at one another to knock them out.With each consecutive hit to the ball, it gains speed, which can make things very interesting, very fast.The game also has a number of different modes from online, to versus, to an extra menu with different things such as a tutorial, training mode, as well as the challenge mode which basically acts as the core single player aspect to the game itself.THE GOOD-Quick and easy to pick up and play gameplay-Addicting-Different game modes and options to choose from-Competitive and great multiplayerRight off the BAT pun intended, one of the best aspects to Lethal League is the pick up and play nature of the game itself, it’s easy to learn and you’ll be smashing your opponents in no time flat, the game features an easy to learn tutorial to help new comers out, but the concept itself is pretty easy to wrap your head around.It’s also extremely addicting, the first time me and my friends started playing this together we couldn’t stop, the quick matches and nature of the game itself lends to the addiction factor big time and it works beautifully.The gameplay itself is fairly unique, almost reminding of pong on steroids with a gorgeous art style and blazing soundtrack to boast its intensity, the game is easy to play, but definitely takes some serious skill and good timing to master it.But easily the BEST aspect to Lethal League is the online multiplayer, whether you’re in a team or free for all, Lethal League truly shines when you’re pitted against your friends as you battle it out and make the ball reach absolute insane levels of speed.You’ve also got access to a variety of different game options if you’re hosting, from changing the speed of the ball itself when you hit it, to a big ball mode, team versus matches, free for all, and a mode where you basically have to hit the opposing team’s target at each end of the map to gain points.The character roster as well all have their own unique abilities as well to mix things up, and you unlock different skins for them as you progress the game and earn “experience” allowing you to level up and unlock the different skins for them and overall really adds to the addictive nature and replayability of the game.Over all, we had TONS of fun playing this for hours on end and is easily one of the best competitive games I’ve played in recent memory.THE BAD-Few core game modes to choose from (not much content) *Minor*Honestly I don’t have much to talk about here, Lethal League does what it does very well, I had no major issues or never felt something was unfair or over powered and the game is very well balanced. Probably the only issue I have is the lack of content, despite just talking about the different game modes to choose from, Lethal League outside of what I mentioned doesn’t offer much for core game modes.If you’re looking for some beefy single player content, you won’t really find it here, sure you’ve got a versus mode where you can pit yourself against the PC at different difficulty settings, as well as a challenge mode that you can beat with each character to gain some achievements but honestly this felt nowhere near as compelling or interesting as the multiplayer.As for the multiplayer, once you’ve played as each specific character, and played the different maps and fiddled around with the match settings a bit, you’ve pretty much seen everything this game has to offer you.But to be honest, this is all pretty minor and I can easily see myself coming back to play this.THE UGLY-Not graphically impressive, it’s quite literally based off a flash game after all-What it lacks in graphical fidelity it more than makes up for it in art style-Amazing soundtrack-Odd game crash during multiplayerWhere we discuss the graphics, soundtrack, and technical aspect of the game.Lethal League won’t wow you in the sense with amazing textures and particle effects like some games might, which is obvious considering the game looks like something you could find on Newgrounds.But what it will wow you with is the fabulous art style it boasts, from the different scenic backgrounds, to the character models and general presentation, what Lethal League lacks in big budget impressive graphics, it more than makes up for in its amazing art style and presentation.And one thing that really adds to this is the AMAZING soundtrack, this is easily one of the best sound tracks I’ve listened to in a game in a long time, the art style and soundtrack over all give me almost a Jet Set Radio vibe, and I love it.However, not everything is perfect, we did have our fair number of freezing issues during online matches, as well as the odd game crash or two in my 5 or so hours I’ve spent with Lethal League, but overall the gameplay itself was bug free during our experience and most of the crashes and freezing were during the online match making.FINAL THOUGHTSAs I said earlier this is probably the most fun I’ve had yet so far with any indie game and I highly recommend you give Lethal League a try if you’ve got some friends looking for a fun, unique, and competitive game, despite some minor technical issues we had, playing this was an absolute blast.If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: Follow Original Curator Group

												SUMMARY: Its like smash and pong on crack. Very fun to play with friends or on local co-op. Gets more and more intense as the round goes on and both parties are screaming their asses off as the balls pierces the fabric of the earthEXPLENATION: Its a fighting game where the player chooses their select character each with its own special ability that is more or less balanced. The object of the game is to hit a small ball back and forth, changing its colour to the player that touched it last, if a player who is not the same colour touches the ball (as in not hit it) they die and lose a life, zero lifes left and the player is eliminated. Now heres the kicker, as the ball gets hit more and more, it gains more and more speed, extreme amounts of speed one could say and the colours of the game starts changing to match the intensity and the speed that the ball is going at. All while a kickass soundtrack plays in the background. Definetly a fun game although I wish more people played online :(

content:
29, 2014
												There are many games which have multiplayer mode and only a number of them ends up as global hits which are played by lots of players and in which connection issues are rarity or aren't issues at all. While this game isn't this kind of title yet, I need to say this game is a little gem which should shine really bright in near future. But let's start from the beginning.Lethal League is a game where your main goal is to control ball and hit it as hard as possible to hurt your opponents and knock them down, while also using unique techniques limited to each of playable characters. Sounds simple, right ? But I assure you it's not that easy, especially when the movement with which ball move after few hits may reach RIDICULOUS speed and hitting the ball itself (or counter it by pressing X which is a kind of a block which stops the movement of it) may be a really tough challenge. This game will test your dexterity, reaction time and timing, which are really crucial here. So in other words I would call this title easy to learn (it's literally jump, hit and block buttons), but hard to fully master. Graphics are as simple as in screenshots, but I need to say they are still estethic and look nice with bright colors mixed in (I also like in overall the style game brings with interesting characters). And I need to mention one more thing, which is really, REALLY crucial - music. My gosh, music in this one is one of the best things I heard in gaming history. Electronic climates created by really talented artists like Grillo, zeroSCAR or Klaus Veen fits the climate of the game perfectly, while being perfectly well made. I would say music alone in this game make this game worth to purchase, it's THAT good. To sum it up game is really well made flash-like game with incredible competitive potential. Game basics are simple to learn, but this game has this crucial element, which make it fun, challenging and mostly work like some sort of a drug, which forces you to play it as much as you can. I give it 9,5/10 as I feel 5 characters is kind of a small numbers of possible options if you ask me. But I assure you - this one will become one of the best gaming hits ever. At least it has great potential to become one.

content:
er 30, 2014
												Game is fun!I've seen many call this game "Smash Brothers meets Pong" and that's roughly correct. Lethal League is similar to Smash titles in its ease of access (being pretty simple to understand and play) and its competitive depth. Its similar to Pong in being focused around the ball, the one lethal element of the game. You and your opponent(s) are striving to hit this ball, tagging it to yourself and making it lethal to your opponent until they successfully hit it back (or miss, get hit, and die). The ball will steadily speed up after every hit as long as players remain alive, ramping up the intensity. Continue this until all but one player have lost all their lives, and only the champion remains!Local and online multiplayer are supported, with 2-4 players. You can play 1v1, FFA, teams, or strikers (similar to soccer) modes. There are a couple different ball types you can try as well to mix things up, along with general options (stock count, time limit, etc.) There is matchmaking, but it's not skill-based (the community isn't large enough to support skill-based matchmaking anyways).The game is great if you want to just hit buttons and peg your friends with baseballs, and also great if you're looking for something with competitive depth. While the execution barrier is fairly low, you have a lot of freedom of movement/options, and the smarter and more experienced player is still favored to win. Regardless, the game does a great job of hypeing the player up, as hits take progressively longer to complete as the ballspeed increases (giving the feeling of them putting more and more force into the ball), and the screen starts to shake, the background changes, 'impact distortions' occur, all the colors go negative, characters get speed afterimages, and finally the stage goes completely white if you get the ballspeed up enough. Each notch of this progressively makes things more intense, especially the first time you see them!The only drawbacks to me of this game is the playerbase size and occasional crashes. This game has seen occasional boons in playerbase (usually following sales), but on average there's about 60-100 people playing at a time. Games go fairly quick, and you usually won't be waiting more than a minute in quickmatch queue (at least during peak EU and NA hours), but you may run into the same people multiple times. What you don't have in quantity, though, you do have in quality. There's almost always a few people in the group chat willing to play, and many are experienced players who are welcoming and helpful. The competitive LL community is, overall, one of the best communities I've been in.The other drawback is a recurring crash that can occur in multiplayer games of more than 2 people. This only occurs maybe once every 6-7 games, but it can get annoying fairly quick. Fortunately, the game loads almost instantly, so getting back in the action is fast. It's annoying but manageable.I highly suggest you try this game out, especially if you have friends to play it with. $15 may be a bit expensive for some (it was well worth it for me, 450 hours of play and counting), but I would definitely recommend this to anyone at $10 or less.

content:
31, 2014
												This is by far the best "casual" fighter in the market. Excellent sense of depth hidden in simple mechanics. When you start out it seems fairly simple like the prototype, but the bunts, supers, and character movement really make the game engaging as time goes on. For example Sonata feels extremely weak early on because of her slow hitting motion and jumps. These are offset by the best early super which is you can get easily while staying high in the air and getting free hits in. Candyman's strengths are obvious with his portal super grabbing easy games off of weaker players but tends to not be as powerful as players get better. Raptor has solid movement and has one of the best late game supers by (fully?) removing the hit stop animation making it sometimes impossible to hit back. Switch seems to be a mid game character with fast movement and his super which redirects the ball. His super has some good potential to net kills fast but becomes much harder to use later in the game. Latch is an all game character with the most broken super which can almost always guarantee kills after 128 speed. The only problem is the online which suffers from is lack of players for non-American/European people. The entire time spent writing this review I have been sitting in queue and still haven't found a game. If you don't have local friends to play with or a tournament scene for this you might not have the best time with this game.

number of helpful: 11 of 11 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
2016
IntroductionHave you ever wondered what it would be like for superheroes (or beings with superpowers) to play various sports? Perhaps dodgeball? Or baseball? No doubt they would take things to a new extreme, with smashes that break the laws of physics and reaction speeds at mere fractions of milliseconds. Lethal League is a little like that. Imagine Super Smash Brothers but on PC and instead of fighting, you're essentially playing dodgeball in a fairly small arena. Things can get real chaotic, but boy is it fun!GameplayLethal League combines sport, with a highly competitive and slightly strategic game that requires you to have good timing, or a good understanding of angles. This does not mean it's a math or physics game. It simply means Lethal League has an extremely high skill ceiling whilst having a very low barrier to entry. Anyone can pick this up with their friends or play vs bots and have a really great time, and those with the best reaction times can duke it out for the top spots.Your goal is to eliminate all your opponents, by hitting the ball into them. The standard game mode allows you to tag the ball which puts it in your colour and makes it pass through you (so that you don't hit yourself). You can also disable ball tagging for a much more challenging experience. Each time you hit the ball, it goes a little faster. You can hit it up or down depending on whether you are in the air or on the ground. If you smash a ball (air hit) the ball speed is doubled. Now this is where the real fun comes in. If you manage to get 3 or more smashes in, the ball speed is going to ramp up so fast that it quickly becomes a blur of lines in various angles. This is where a knowledge of angles can help you to overcome your opponent. The maximum speed seems to be capped at 1 million. As you break through known speed limits, your hits gradually have a longer delay but the ball speed is so fast that it becomes ALMOST impossible to react to it. You're likely going to struggle with this until you learn the timing windows for various hits, and it is oh so satisfying to counter a ball ping-ponging across the room at over 100,000 (whatever the speed measurement is) into your opponent.You can also bunt the ball in various directions, temporarily slowing it down and allowing you to regain control and possibly change its direction. This is used in combination with regular hits to quickly rack up speed or pull off an unexpectedly fast smash, because bunting a ball reduces the delay on a hit (even the insanely fast ones that require 2-4 seconds of delay) to almost nothing. CharactersThere are 6 characters to choose from and each of them have distinct strengths and weaknesses. Some of them can jump higher than others, some can jump off walls indefinitely etc. This alone would make it fun, however the devs decided this is not enough so they added special abilities. Where do I even begin? Special abilities can drastically change the course of a match in an instant! By hitting the ball you gain charges of your special meter. At 4 charges you can use the ability by double tapping the regular hitting button. Each character has their own unique move that you'll discover on your own, and it adds so much more fun to the game along with previously mentioned elements.VisualsThe visual style of this game is unique, but still quite simple. Characters have some lovely color variations and stages are fairly well designed.AudioI absolutely love the music in this game, as well as the other assorted sounds in the game. When you break the sound barrier, the hit sounds are so impactful and sound like rockets or small bombs going off.Other ThoughtsRunning at 60 FPS is pretty much required to be able to learn your timings properly. The first time I ran the game, it had some very weird frame drops that may have been an issue on my side, but it initially turned me off from the game. However subsequent play sessions did not have that issue, so it must have been some other unrelated issue. The game is very lightweight and runs flawlessly.I would have liked to see more characters in the game, as 6 is hardly a roster of characters compared to other games in this kind of genre. I mean not even the Scout from TF2? That's an iconic character that would have been perfect here.SummaryLethal League is the type of game you can pick up at any time and play with friends. Even as a solo player, you'll find that the bots are quite challenging, and there's enough single player content to keep you interested for even a couple days. The gamplay is fun and rewarding, and is definitely worth checking out if you're interested in a fun, fast, sport-action game.8/10 - The game that destroys friendshipsIf you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up. You can also find more reviews over at http://www.completingthebackloggroup.com/Please also check out Completing the Backlog's Curator page here - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

content:
, 2016
												Lethal League is a what you get when you cross a fighting game with dodgeball in all the best ways.  Players jockey to control a small ball, hitting it around the screen in an attempt to knock out eachother.  Every hit on the ball speeds it up, and it quickly moves from an easy to predict slow moving projectile to a streak that bounces around the screen, ricocheting off ceiling, walls, and floor to take out players.  This simple set up leads to an exciting and incredibly fun game.  Unlike most fighting games, there are no long lists of special moves to learn and memorize (each character has slightly differnt angles they will hit the ball at, and a special move that can be powered up during play and used, but no difficult button combos are required for any moves).  This makes the game very intuitive and easy for players to jump in and start playing, even if you are not into fighters.  However, the interplay between player and their specials does lead to a suprising amount of depth in the combat, and learning the timing to intercept balls as they come off of other players at higher speeds will take practice.  If I had any criticisms for the game, it would be that the simplicity of it can be a double edged sword.  Games can start feeling repetative during long play sessions.  Game options can extend this a bit, but in the end most feel gimicky and I find myself losing interest after 30-60 minutes.  However, that being said, I still find myself coming back to this game to get in a few quick rounds against friends when we don't have time for a long playsession, or to finish out a night of gaming.  And that is where the game shines imho, quick bursts of action and excitement when I don't have the time to spend hours playing.This games perfectly fills a niche in my gaming library.  It is well worth the price (and worth getting a few extra copies for your friends as well).  An unreserved thumbs up from me.

content:
31, 2014
												Lethal League (LL) is the quintessence of competitive arcade gameplay. Being completely free of over complication, Team Reptile have fortunately channelled the most special elements of the nostalgic games of the golden era, where a sole focus on gameplay has driven design and development. The result being a game with no apparent story, not character progression, and no cheap ways of making you feel as though you should be playing the game, instead it slaps you in the face with a fresh take on Fighters, that is plain and simply, unsullied fun.The gameplay and structure of LL lends itself perfectly to the resolution of longstanding disagreements (1-on-1 Fights), bouts of personal worth and glory (4 way FFA), and also to bond-building exercises (2-on-2 Team Fights). The beautiful thing about the simple gameplay is it works so well not only in the hectic 4-way FFA, but also in 1-on-1 combat, where the simple mechanics eventually boil down to a game of whits, where you are more trying to force the other player/s to swing at the wrong point, or you are trying to think and act fast enough to catch them off-guard.That long winded jargon can be distilled down to; this game is perfect for playing with friends, and that is exactly how it should be consumed. This game has one of those qualities where if you get served too hard, you will hate it; so take it in with friends and you will instantly see the gratifying outcome of learning together, while also pulling off some badass manoeuvres resulting in you all squealing like manly Girl Scouts. We have not tried it in Online Play as my internet services would make the game run like an interactive slideshow. But we can safely say that by grabbing a few ales, a few controllers, and huddling around your PC, you will be parting in the finest display of competition I have seen in a video games since Mario Party 64.Team Reptile have not given this game a huge amount of content, with 5 characters and 6 Levels, BUT, the content in the game is so perfectly polished, I question whether the development team is really as small as they say. We would love to see more playable characters and levels in the future just to give the game that bit of spice, but where it stands now is a testament to where AAA game development falls short in modern game development; where such heavy focus on being the next money making machine makes games lose that…specialness.From a developer’s standpoint this game has soul, you can feel the love that went into it when you play it. So get it, you won’t be disappointed.3 / 3 Worth Playing-C

												Lethal League is a truly hillarious, over the top take on pong and fighting games.The general concept is to defeat your opponentt and reduce their stocks (think smash bros) by smashing them with the ball. The ball will deal damage to your opponents after you hit it, but can be hit by them, which can then cause it to deal damage to you. As in pong, you keep rallying the ball back and forth, with it getting faster and faster until one of you is hit, at which point you lose a life and the ball resets. What sounds like a very simple concept rapidly becomes a hillarious series of "Oh ♥♥♥♥!" moments in which the ball is going so incredibly fast that you'd think it impossible to hit, but then someone does, and it gets even faster.Throw in a bunch of colourful and creative characters and stages, along with an incredible sound track, and some very fancy and flashy visual and sound effects that wouldn't feel out of place in an Anime or Manga, and you get an enjoyable and hillarious experience.Would reccomend playing with friends (up to 4 player) for added hillarity and fun.

content:
er 6, 2014
tl;dr -> Ultimate dodgeball - but with objects to hit the ball at your opponents - that can get to Dragon Ball Z-level speeds and ruin friendships forever.My brother was really interested in this game, so I got it for him - eventually, I got interested enough from watching it to buy a few copies for myself and some friends. If you like projectile-based fighting, multiplayer frenzies (both local and online), flashy animations and trick shots, and simplistic (but very fleshed-out) gameplay mechanics, then you will enjoy this game.The aesthetics are very good - the character models are nice, and the level of detail put into the visuals is well-done. The music is set to a single, level-specific track, but the playlist is pretty good and matches the atmosphere of the game. The special effects are fantastic, and the background will even turn completely white once you achieve ball speeds nearing 1 million. The controls are easy to learn, but mastering them will take a bit of time. The practice is great for getting you familiarized with the gameplay mechanics, and there are many well-written guides available to teach you the advanced techniques. You can play with a controller, and I personally prefer this over the keyboard. The learning curve is moderate to difficult, the most challenging thing being how quickly you can understand the timing mechanic. The main goal in Lethal League is to hit your opponent with the ball. By default setting, you cannot get hit by the ball if you've hit it last (indicated by the ball's outline matching your assigned color). If a ball is "tagged" with your color, it will pass through you and any allies, however, you can also hit it again. Each time you hit the ball, it's speed will increase and your special gauge will fill up by one bar (to a total of 4). Bunting the ball and hitting it before it touches a surface will fill your special meter by 2 (and serves other purposes). A bunted ball will have a pinkish outline, indicating that it is a "free" ball - anyone can hit it, and it is not hostile to any player until it is hit. When a burst (round) is over, the first player to have been knocked out in the previous round will have possession of the ball, indicated by a matching outline around it. After a few seconds, however, it will lose it's outline, allowing anyone to hit it.At higher speeds, hitting the ball will cause a hit lag animation, where your character will stay in one spot to charge up, then release the ball. During this time, all other characters can move around to try to position to hit or dodge the ball. There is a mirrored ball-release gauge at the bottom center of the screen, which is a critical tool to use - it will show you how long you have before the ball is released from the hit lag animation. Traditionally, at slow speeds, the gauge will fill up super fast. Bunting is important because a successful hit following one will shorten the ball-release gauge time. The different characters telegraph their moves, so bunting during a long rally (back-and-forth hits) can really help you throw off people's reaction time if they're expecting you to hit a ball immediately back at them. Each character has a unique special, and many of them allow you to do things like bypass the ball-release gauge time (causing the ball to be released regardless of the gauge status), redirect the ball's trajectory (especially dangerous when people have positioned in an angle to catch the ball), or even curve the ball (super awesome trick shot potential). One character has a special that allows the ball to phase through the map (so instead of bouncing, it will continue through and appear on the opposite side). The characters also differ in playstyle, and you will notice things like quicker hits for some, higher jumps, longer hit range, etc. One character, Sonata, can double jump. Raptor, who cannot double jump and has a fairly short vertical range, compensates for this by being able to wall hang and wall jump. Latch can, well, latch onto the wall, moving up and down freely. If you and an opponent swing at each other at the same time, you will clash, pushing each other backwards and stun-locking you for a few seconds. This is especially dangerous if you are stun-locked by an opponent who just finished hitting the ball forward because it will instantly hit you. This game really rewards skill and patience - if you just spam the hit/bunt button, you will get hit by the fall often because it takes time for each character to recover from the hit/bunt animation, leaving you vulnerable. You can even do something as face the wrong way, and will meet a sudden (temporary) death.There is a singleplayer challenge mode you can do, which has the same opponents regardless of which character you pick, and a unique boss match. The game's AI is fairly challenging, and at times seems to randomly turn up to a "destroy all hope in the human opponent" rating. There are other variants to play, like a score attack (versus stock), and a team scoring game where you have to hit a target on the opposite side (you cannot hit each other in this mode).Overall, the game is extremely fun, and will be enjoyed by people who like projectile-based fighting.Highly recommend!Cheers,DJSF @DJSF's Rogue Reviews

content:
, 2016
												I've been playing this game for a decent amount of time now, and I have almost nothing but positive things to say about it.- It's a very fast paced game with a rather high skill cap to achieve.- Easy(ish) to learn, and all around fun to play for hours on end.- A somewhat small yet very friendly community towards all players.- Community held tournies keep the playerbase intact and alive.- The game can be played with either keyboard or controller with only slight advantages using the controller.- The game is brutal with it's matchmaking and really lets you know what you're in for when you face opponents with over 1k+ hours. (It's okay to suck, you'll just suck less next time!)- The game runs smoothly consistently; ie: no sudden frame drops, no visual tearing, etc.One of the only bad things I've found about this game so far is how long it can take to get a matchmaking game sometimes, but the gameplay definitely overwhelms that con so it all works out in the end.I give this game an honest 10/10, it's really a great game but sadly doesn't have as much of a player following as I wish it did.

												Lethal League is an extremely fun fighting game up to 4 players fighting with super balls to take down each other.Seriously it's very addicting if you have friends to play with.You have "Free for All", "Team Deathmatch" and "Strikers" modes, and several characters to choose from and each character has unique movements and abilities.However, i never found a multiplayer game, i think the game is dead, but had a lot of fun playing it locally with my nephew.Technically the game is smooth, bug-free and very stable while the graphics are cartoonish.Single Player: 7.5/10Multiplayer: 10/10Totally Recommended to buy it if you have friends, if not check the forums to get players to play together.

number of helpful: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 22, 2014
												This game is a wallball-esque/tennis combat system where you time your swings and kick the ball back to the opponent in hopes to hit him before he has time to respond to the ball. Sounds too simple to be fun, right?Wrong. My friend and I bought this game as a bit of a joke but ended up playing it for hours. I had raw fun while playing this, the kind that you experience only rarely in quality indie titles like Hotline Miami, Skullgirls, etc.With 2-3 different game modes, 6 characters, and 7 maps this game is quite small, but what it lacks in size it makes up for in strength. The characters are unique, with mildly entertaining special moves for each of them. The maps each have their own music (The music is surprisingly good in this game). The most interesting aspect of the game is the D-pad+Y shout out. You can taunt, or interact, with your opponent by stating,"Oops", "Wow", "Nice", and "Bring it on". The tricky part of the game is the ball speed. As you paddle back and forth the ball speed will increase and you'll have to be much more instinctive about your response times. I saw an achievement for 1,000,000 ball speed. My friend and I have only gotten to 1,000. Is it a good game? Yes. Is it worth $10-$14? Not really, but you can always get it on sale.

er 29, 2016
	TL;DR: I reccomend Lethal League to people who have friends that also play Lethal League. Pros:-Good music-Easy to learn, hard to master -Good controls-Fun with friendsCons:-Small bugs-Boring single player-Not updated too often-Matchmaking is clunky-Costs too much (I recommend waiting until this game is on sale or buying it off G2@)Rating: 7/10Honestly I have had some of the best times with my friends playing Lethal League. The feeling of tying all of your hits together and taking out your opponent is one of the most rewarding feelings I have ever had in a video game. This game has been fun (for me) ever since the day I got it to now. Although I love this game very much, I don't think it is for everyone. If you don't have any other friends who own this game, then I think you should either buy the four pack, or just not bother buying the game. The single player is boring and repetitve and the matchmaking isn't really worth your time due to connection issues and bugs.

												TL:DR Whether you're good at fighters or not, this game is extremely fun and easy to learn, BUY IT!Alright. Welp. This game is GREAT. Lethal League is a unique fighting time that's pretty much based on timing. You must hit the ball in time so your opponent doesn't kill you. You're basically playing ball tag with your opponent. You try to hit the ball to each other and whoever hits too early or doesn't pay attention will get hit and die. I'm kinda bad at explaining this so maybe it doesn't sound like the funnest game, but trust me ITS FUN! You know one thing I really like about this game? Call me a f*cking casualist if you want, but, ya know, it takes more Rythm than skill. This game you can ACTUALLY WIN without hours and hours of experience. Unlike Skullgirls, where you need to watch sh*t to learn combos or take hours to learn on your own or even been born in the 80s playing fighters at da arcade. The thing is about Skullgirls, if you go in online with a couple hours of play, you'll get the sh*t beat out of you. I guess what I'm saying is, I'm not really a fan of arcade fighters. My issue with dem arcade fighters is the crazy ♥♥♥ combos you have to make to do powerful attacks. But, anyway yea. BUY LETHAL LEAGUE!!! It's a competitive and Casual game!

content:
31, 2014
												I eye my top-heavy crocodile opponent from across the field as a purple coated ball begins to spawn between us. He points his stout towards the object, knowing that he's going to smash this into my cold, yellow face. Not today, Latch. Not today.The ball materializes and we rush towards it. My cane is already extended for an over the head smash to hit the reptilian foe below me. Time seems to stop as I connect with the latent power resting within the ball. The crocodile was quick to react and seemed to stop all momentum I had with my initial hit with one tap of his nose. The ball soared over me, and before I connected with the ground the crocodile was already rallying the ball against a wall, hoping to power up another devastating blow.I rush to intervene in his sadistic wall-ball ritual, tapping the ball out of his rhythm at an upwards angle. Furious, Latch's eyes glowed red towards the cane that brought an end to his games. He claws the wall in front of him and begins to climb up its structure to catch up to the ball. Flipping outwards, he catches the ball in his mouth and my world goes dark. All I can see is the crocodile's burning descent from the wall, his eyes reflecting my helpless yellow face.I jump upwards to dodge the assult, but Latch releases the saliva-covered ball angled with precision towards my jump peak. The counter at the bottom reads into the hundreds, and I know that reflecting this is going to take all the luck in my thin smiley-faced bones. My cane relexively reaches in defense, and this was all the luck I needed. The ball's momentum is reversed right at the crocodile's pointed nose. But what stops him from doing exactly what I just did?I try to land a second hit and throw Latch off his prediction. He sees this and attempts to outsmart my own moves. We negate each other's attacks with a twang of cane and stout, the ball landing just behind Latch. I see it bounce off the corners of the rotting arena with bliding speed, and I process that it's coming right back at me. Cane out, I bunt the ball directly downwards into where the crocodile attempts another intervention. His tail whips around, but he is too early.The ball lightly bounces off the top of his scaly skull, and he's sent below the arena.BURST 2, BEGIN!

content:
y 3
												It's a fighting game, it's pong, it's expressive, it's a party game, and I never would have bought it if I wasn't introduced to it at a party, because trailers have a really hard time capturing why it's so much fun.The gameplay lives off a wide array of mechanics that are all accessed by basic movement keys and 2 more buttons. Different characters don't only have unique special abilities as showcased in the trailer but also subtle differences in the way they move, their hitboxes and the angles in which they hit the ball.At first, the game is just enjoyable without having any clue of what's even happening, but once you play more you get an idea of how high the skill ceiling actually is. To become a master, you don't only need high knowledge of/experience with the characters and perfect reactions, but also the ability to read, surprise and outsmart your opponent.

												Just started to play and what I've seen so far is enough to recommend this game to everyone.Mechanics are rock solid (amazing with every game mode, from 1v1 to 2v2 to free for all)Animations are really well done and backgrounds are just as simple as fitting to create a futuristic (cyberpunk) atmosphere.Music, just a cherry on top, blends perfectly and gives a certain enjoyable rhythm to the matches.It's not a "deep" fighting game, but it is definitely a unique one (no other fighting/brawling games have a dodgeball-like mechanic as far as I know) and even if there are no fancy commands/moves it gets pretty technical with angles/feints/tactics.Again, strongly recommended to everyone.

												There’s so many addicting yet simply games, but Lethal League isn’t one of them. It’s a sort of a dodgeball, or squash rather, where you hit a ball (obviously) which gets faster and faster any time you score a combo. Your goal is to K.O. your opponent. Easy to pick up rules makes a very simple concept for the game that anyone’ll understand, but it gets so old very quickly at the same time. Seriously it’s just boring as hell. I’m certainly not, so I’m not recommending it.

number of helpful: 14 of 24 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
er 7, 2015
												I usually don't write reviews after only playing for a half hour. I tend to wait until I've either finished the game or played a large enough portion before getting bored with it to come to a valid conclusion.What I've seen of Lethal League so far indicates that it's a supremely addictive game. Simple mechanics are coupled with a very high skill ceiling and lots of challenge, which over the course of each match escalates to ludicrous heights. Each character has a very different set of abilities beyond simply tossing the ball around and the combination of a variety of characters make on-the-fly strategizing against them very entertaining. Overall I'd give Lethal League a big recommendation on that front.However, the connection issues are what absolutely kill this game for me at the moment. Every other match doesn't load properly and I've had plenty of disconnects even with players in my own region. Mind you that I have a 15MB/s (that's Megabyte, not Megabit) connection where my PC is connected via Ethernet cable and not Wi-Fi, so my connection is about as solid as you can get, and yet it still fails around 50% of the time. I won't cry about connection times since I realize that they're mostly down to the amount of active players, but once a connection is established, it's amazing how bad the game manages to function. Not to mention that when the game does actually hang up and never starts the next match, you can't simply get out again by pressing Escape or any other keys. You have to terminate the application with Alt+F4 every single time this happens, and it can get very annoying. I was fortunate enough to have bought the game with the recent Humble Monthly, so it cost me around $1.2, or 90% less than what's asked for here on Steam, which is why I'll keep the game and give it a mild pass in order to see if the issues get resolved in the future. But for the record, had I paid full price, I'd have refunded this broken mess immediately. Which is unfortunate, a game with solid mechanics and the potential for hours of fun is shot in the kneecaps by terrible connection issues.If the issues get resolved, I will edit this review to reflect any future changes made here.

er 23, 2016
												One of the most insane fighting games I have ever experienced. Lethal League takes the fun party game feel, and colorful roster of characters from Smash Brothers. And combines it with the the most intense dodgeball game in the universe. The only way for you to knock out your opponent is to smack the ball in to their face. Bring in 2 or 3 of your friends and you have fun in its purest and hypest form. The single player is a challenge, especially the final boss. You'd really have to dedicate yourself enough to actually become skilled enough to stand toe to toe with it (or you could actually be good at video games, which I am not). Overall a fantastic fighting game, and if there is even a chance of it getting a sequel I'm all on board.

												So basically you start out hitting a ball at pretty decent speeds until one of you gets their skull cracked open. The longer you survive the more ridiculous it gets, to the point where I'm pretty sure I was hitting the ball at light speed. It was terrifying and hilarious. Especially since faster hits have weird visual effects on maps (like, on one map all the windows break, an eclipse happens, and rioting mobs appear.) that then vanish when the ball is no longer being hit. Its like youre ripping into an alternate dimension.I should mention that my first (and so far only) play session lasted two whole hours, but felt closer to 30 mins. So, overall, pretty damn great. I usually complain a lot in reviews (...on Amazon. I rarely do Steam reviews) but I don't even have any complaints about this.If you're unsure about buying it, just do. You won't regret it.

content:
8, 2015
												Lethal League is a competitive "battle pong" that has you take control of one of six players, each with different styles of play, in a deadly game of tag-by-baseball. The fundamentals of the game are pretty simple: Hit the ball and it changes to your color and will damage every enemy player but not yourself. Bunting will send the ball upward and give you a chance to reposition for a better attack. Any time you hit the ball you build up a super meter that will allow you to perform a special attack once filled. The majority of strategy in LL revolves around two things: hit meter/lag, and angles. You'll need to pay attention to the hit meter at the bottom of the screen to know how much longer it will be before the hit lag ends and the ball continues on in play. Knowing when it will re-enter play will allow you to position yourself accordingly and begin your counter attack. Another important factor is being aware of the angle the ball takes (or will take if you can predict it) since knowing that will allow you to take control of it with your own strike or avoid getting knocked out. Lethal League basically has two modes spread across several categories: Versus (Online/Local/Challenge) and Strikers. Versus is the basic game mode where you have a limited number of life stocks and the game ends when you or your team run out of them. Strikers puts you in position of a goal that you must keep the enemy team from hitting with an enemy-charged ball. There is also a point game in the challenge mode which is like versus but you play until one player gets a set number of kills.Since the game only has six playable characters, six stages, and really just two modes (only one of which seem to be played online: versus). You'll probably find yourself running out of things to do without having a bunch of friends to play with. Not to mention the online community is rather small and it can take anywhere from 5-15 minutes just to find a match, and when you do find a match, having any kind of lag between the players can make some rounds pretty difficult as the ball bounces and hit lag can become downright unpredictable. There are definitely some fun times to be had when you get matched up with a decent opponent, though.I would recommend grabbing this game somewhere around $5 or cheaper to really get your money's worth. It's not a bad game per-se, it just needs more content.

content:
er 8, 2014
												Lethal League is a game that I could only describe as "A special kind of addicting". While it's at its best in multiplayer, this gem of a game will be able to keep any player enveloped for a good amount of time after they start playing. Playing as a sort of cross between Super Smash Brothers and Pong, Lethal League employs up to 4 player in a fight to the death where the only means of downing an opponent is to bat an anti-gravity baseball into them. The characters, while limited at the moment, are all a joy to control and all have interesting designs, my personal favorite of the bunch being Candyman. Lethal League really is a blast to play, and is my personal pick for Indie Game of the Year. If you ever pick it, chances are that you won't be putting it down for a very long while.

content:
er 1, 2014
												Ok, so first of all, some people think that the actual content that this game offers doesn't really justify it's price. I don't share this opinion, the game isn't really all that expensive and while the content may be limited, there is just a lot of fun to be had with it. However, I still strongly urge anyone who considers buying Lethal League to get some friends to play this game with and buy a 2 or a 4-pack and split the price. The multipacks are pretty good deals, and the game is the most fun when you are playing it with a friend anyway.Now that we got that out of the way, let's talk about why you should buy this game, because you absolutely should.Lethal League is a projectile based 2-D fighter with an interesting, kind of jet-set-like style to it. It features a surprisingly good soundtrack that really complements the gameplay as well as the overall feel of the game. Lethal League actually has very few mechanics, yet still provides a decent amount of depth, so it is pretty easy to pick up while being able to entertain and challenge you for a long amount of time. Basically, the goal in this game is to hit your opponent with an anti-gravity-ball which will cause them to lose one life instantly. You can hit or bunt the ball in various fashions to make it reach ludicrious speeds and bounce around in crazy patterns, and believe me, it's just mad fun. The sheer insanity of the gameplay paired with the incredible soundtrack and cool visual just makes it a blast to watch or play. There are currently six characters which differ in mobility and special moves, as well as the angles they can make the ball travel at.The game doesn't really offer all that interesting offline modes, but it's most enjoyable in multyplayer anyway. You can play free for alls, team fights and 1v1s. Lethal League, just like Skullgirls, uses GGPO and it results in super smooth feeling online play.So, if the concept sounds at least a bit appealing to you and you have someone to play it with, you really owe yourself to pick it up, especially since there are not much games that are able to offer you a similar expierence out there.

												If you're considering buying this game to play it with friends, stop reading reviews and just buy itIf you don't have fun, I will personally come to your house and refund you the money you spentFun party game with a very competitive multiplayer scene, similar to Smash BrosVery simple, intuitive mechanics - it's easy to pick up and play, while maintaining a high skill ceiling (see: candychaining)Some mechanics aren't presented with much depth in the tutorial, so consider spending a while on Google to learn about parrying and Switch's specialOnline will have you disconnect once or twice before you can connect to an opponent, but once you find a game it can continue as long as you like, I've had one 1v1 go on for a few hours - relatively short queues, 3 minutes is considered a long queue imoAll that being said, I picked up this game recently and have been hooked ever since, and I don't see myself losing interest any time soonEDIT: One year post-review and the online is mostly dead. The only people playing right now are the die-hards and tryhards, which makes it difficult to learn the game. Pick it up if you plan to play with friends or if the game is on sale.

content:
31, 2016
												Lethal League is a competative baseball/dodgeball hybrid that supports up to four players in one match. With each strike of the ball, the speed is doubled, sometimes even quadrupled (and in serious cases, maxed at one million). Maybe you and a few friends sit on the couch and hit the ball back and forth a few times. Maybe it's you and a stranger online. Regardless, every hit and dodge are anxiety and adrenaline riddled. With more than four friends who've enjoyed this game with me, we've never experienced any rage or upsetting losses, only awe at how insane it is to bunt the ball at such ridiculous speeds and then pelt it right back at the poor soul who bashed it towards you in the first place. Each character has a special ability that makes the matches all that much more interesting once they've filled their blue bar. Beware Dice and Candy Man. There's also an interesting secret character which you can play as in local matches; I'll let you google the code for yourself.My friends and I give this game a 10/10 for competative shenanigans and I give it a 9/10 for the minor network bugs. Worth the price, but I'm glad I snagged it on the humblebundle for a buck.

While you're at it grab the 4 player pack for you and your buddies. The game is very lightweight and loads quickly, I feel just about any computer can handle it.

y 10, 2016
												A game that seems simple at first glance, but has a surprisingly high skill ceiling. This unique "fighting" game still has me on the edge of my seat, with intense high-speed battles.Lethal League plays a bit differently than other fighting games, since you have little effect on your opponent directly. Instead, to knock them out, you must hit a levitating ball and land a direct hit, while your opponent tries to do the same to you. Mind-games come into play as you can hit the ball under an angle up and down, which causes it to bounce rapidly around the stage!Other features: Sweet music and high moddability (Sprites, music, UI).While the GGPO connection actually works great (A high ping player will bring down any game, really) once the match has started, there are some issues when starting the match, occasionally locking up the game. The devs seem to want to try to fix this issue currently, so hopefully this (pretty big) flaw will be sorted out soon.

content:
, 2015
												There's not a lot to say about Lethal League. And that's by no means a bad thing, I wish I could say a lot of things about this game, because I find it to be one of the better PvP games I've played in a long time. The game is simple: think of it like... racketball, with an anime escalation twist. Battle Pong. The game gives you a good amount of option, the characters are varied, and the game is simple enough to pick up and play, but just complex enough to really garner competitive spirit. My only complaint (and this goes for a lot of fighters, as well) is that certain parts of the system are not presented to player really at all. But other than that, Lethal League is a well crafted game that's simply a blast to play.

												I said this might be the next Windammers, but it's a whole step beyond that. It's a 4 player party with working internet play that is essentially the time-tested gameplay of Pong mixed with the brutality of Super Dodge Ball at supersonic speeds. It just feels super satisfying to hit that ball, it's pure excitement. It's also got actually challenging challenges, working Internet play using the GGPO framework (which is a marvel in itself) and some unlockables.It's light on content, but when what you have is SO GOOD, i'm not going to complain about that. A nice simple game with askill ceiling of practically infinite height, the ultimate duel for bragging rights. If you take home 1st in this you will KNOW you earned it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
er 8, 2014
												The best way to describe Lethal League is as a simplification of the fighter genre mixed with a projectile game.Divekick did that in that fact that instead of having complicated moves, it became more about timing and mind games.Lethal League does that in your positioning, your timing (although its pretty easy to get good at that), and your ability to change things up enough to freak out the opponent. If you don't mess with their head, and you're both good at the timing and positioning, the game can go on for a long time.It's a lot about making less mistakes than the other person. In fact, that's pretty much how you win.But enough about that, why should you play this game?PROS:- Easy to just play, easy to get good at, but relatively hard to get REALLY good at- Can keep you busy with just the singleplayer, but has a decent online matchmaking system, as well as local and online 4 player, similar to smash bros- Good at not frustrating the player, the most fun way to play if the best way to win- Gameplay that manages to be fast but also slow??? It works, trust me- Awesome music- Funky art- No weak ♥♥♥♥CONS:- Small character roster (Also a pro because it's easier to learn everything)- Much lower skill cap than other fighters (doesn't mean it can't be competetive)- Really grindy level up system (at least you get rewards for every level in the form of colour palletes and different balls which change up gameplay)In short, if you like unique fighters, or Jet Set Radio, or both (like me), this game should be appealing to you.Also a good party game. Not that I'd know.

content:
r 14, 2014
												Definitely my pick for the most fun to be had in a game in several years! Lethal League is a projectile fighting game which starts off easy to learn, then quickly scales into either a chaotic mess of fun to be had with your friends or a very interesting competitive experience. With a gameplay system that's much deeper than it would seem at a glance, Lethal League provides fun to whoever is willing to give it a shot, and I'd highly recommend you fork out a few bucks for the game that keeps on giving.It being a multiplayer game, it does suffer from the usual lack of opponents issue when you want to play against someone in less than ideal circumstances. The art of the game certainly isn't particularly striking or unique in any way, just enough so to serve its purpose. Lethal League also suffers from a lack of diverse content, but that's forgivable as what content there is has been polished to a mirror shine.Every shortcoming listed is easily ignored in favor of a Higher Fun, and you should definitely get in on the chaos everyone's talking about!

content:
4, 2016
												Lethal League. Jolly ol' Lethal League.What can I say about this game, considering I just got it yesterday? A lot. I guess.THE STORY:There is no story. :/THE GAMEPLAY:Imagine Super Smash Bros. with no platforms floating in the sky. Then, add dodgeball into the mix. Yeah. Dodgeball. Who doesn't like that maniacal, murderous hellfest of a game? It's better than it sounds though, which means there won't be any dodgeballs flying at your literal face. Realism.The controls are pretty simple. You use the left and right arrow keys to move... fairly simple. Z to attack... sure. X to stop the ball from zip-zapping all over the place... cool. Spacebar to jump... aweso--Wait a sec... the Spacebar to jump? That's a bit unexpected for a Steam game, don't you think?When you hit the ball, you can use the up and down keys to set the angle you're going to hit the ball with.You have 8 lives by default (you can change it in settings) and it's your job to knock out your opponents one by one. When the ball is your colour, it can't hurt you at all. Or can it? I have no idea.In terms of colours, P1 has red, P2 has blue, P3 has yellow and P4 has green. Cool.Like Smash Bros, there are different skins (or "flavours") for each character. None of the skins, heck, none of the characters play any different. So really, you can just choose any character without any problems.Unless...The special attacks!Each character has their own special attack. Candyman has Candyball (in which the ball can teleport through walls and look like an awesome face while it's at it), Latch has...Um......Serves me right for only playing as Candyman.What can I say? I love him and his jawbreakers. No matter how weird they taste. (innuendo not intended)You can hit the ball 4 times until you can use your special attack. Just press Z two times. It doesn't always work though.THE GAMEMODES:Online, versus, challenge and training. That's it.But, there are sub-gamemodes in the versus mode. There's free-for-all (self-explanatory), team (again, self explanatory) and strikers (each team has to hit the ball in the goals they're trying to attack. In other words... soccer.THE VISUALS:The visuals are kinda like the 2003 Ninja Turtles cartoon. Cartoonish, but pretty edgy as well. The graphics look a bit pixel-y, but they do the job well.THE MUSIC:Not the best soundtrack. The tracks are pretty cool, but I'd be screwed if I remember what they sound like.They're better than my music though. I'll tell you that.PROGRESSION:Each time you play the game, you earn EXP. You all know what that is. Progressing to more levels gives you new "flavours" to try out. I especially like the black Candyman. He tastes like licorice.FINAL VERDICT:The game is pretty fun and memorable, and it's one of the most innovative Steam games I've seen (and this game was made in the 2010's, when Call of Duty was still around). Sadly, there is no local multiplayer, but I'll forgive it, considering that it's not frickin' Fireboy and Watergirl.My final word on this game is that this game is... GREAT.

content:
3, 2015
												This is probably one of the best indie 'Brawler' games out currently if not the best. It's unique, having you bat an increasingly-speed ball around in attempts to knock out all other opponents, but also still very competitive. There is no ranked play from the time that I played, and there is really no real content either than just the main arena. Each character is very unique in their own ways while still being very balanced as well which is kind of hard to do in Brawlers from what I've seen. There is even a main campaign that is actually challenging and interesting, another thing Brawlers can't seem to get.I keep saying 'Brawler' because it is described as a fighting game and your goal is, technically, to bat your opponents out of the arena. Due to it's lack of content though you're gonna get your greatest enjoyment from playing with friends. There is no collectibles or secrets or hidden characters or anything so there isn't a whole lot more to do than just the arena, if I hadn't made that clear. This game would have to earn a 4/5 from me but it could easily get a 5 if they add more content.

content:
7, 2015
												It's really addicting. It's the perfect pick-up-and-play game that epitomizes the "easy to learn, hard to master" mechanics of a fighting game. It looks and feels like an old arcade game with very simple controls (run, jump, swing, bunt), but the unique spin it takes on the fighting game genre is very refreshing and it creates a very enjoyable atmosphere, even for those that are not a fan of fighting games such as myself. The soundtrack is upbeat and plays along well with the arcade style. My only complaints are that you can't create a public room with your friends in it, and then search for more to fill the lobby. It's either your friends in a private game, or strangers in a public, unless you are lucky enough to be selected as the host in a public room and there is an empty spot for a friend. At $14, the small amount of content (six characters, seven maps, three game modes) isn't a surprise or a rip-off. You get what you pay for; a fun, whacky mix between Pong and Street Fighter that just feels like a classic you've missed out on.

content:
er 14, 2015
												Most fun I've ever had in any local multiplayer game, even if I keep losing TT_TT---ReviewAs I have said, Lethal League is a very fun multiplayer game. It is easy to learn but hard to master, and has a pretty high skill cap.Pros: Memorable catchy house music. A unique concept of pong/baseball/fighting all combined into one game that is really blood-pumping and may cause some screaming if you're playing a LAN. Solid mechanics The controls are tight 6 different characters you can choose from with different abilities (and hit angles). You can play in quick short bursts, maybe when you're queuing for a Dota 2 game, CSGO, anything really. The art is unique. The animations are very smooth. The voice acting isn't cringe-worthy and is very well done. Playing with lag is somewhat manageable, unlike in some FPS and other games where lag is very important to not have. Hardly any bugs.Cons: Current playerbase isn't too big so actually finding a game is sometimes impossible. You can check on SteamDB[steamdb.info] to see how many players are playing at the moment so you can actually find an opponent. Price is a bit too expensive for some people. Rare crashes.That's all I could think of for cons, really.WishlistThe things I wish was in the game More characters A cheaper price to increase the playerbaseFINAL VERDICT:85/100This game is really different to most other fighting games, if you can afford it, buy it when it is on sale, usually it's around $5, so get it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
29, 2015
												What can I say about Lethal League that hasn't already been said? It's a fantastic game, and one worth playing for quite a while! Team Reptile did an amazing job with this title, ranging from the excellent gameplay, to the beautiful soundtrack, even to the art the game displays so well. Let's have a jawbreaker and take a look, shall we? Intro: Lethal League is a game that will test you and make sure you make the right decisions, or you're going to strike out fast! The aim of the game is to smack a ball and try to hit your opponent with it to knock him out, which makes him lose a piece of health. Everytime you hit the ball it turns your color so you can't get hit until he hits it back! You play as one of six total characters: Raptor, Switch, Candyman, Sonata, Latch, and Dice. Each character hits the ball in different angles and has their own jump heights and abilities that make each of them stand out from one another. You've got your basic 15 year old baseball player, all the way down to a cyborg crocodile that uses his tail to hit the ball and a robot with a skateboard!Gameplay: The gameplay in Lethal League is absolutely amazing. It is so fun making the ball go thousands of miles per hour and always wondering if you'll hit the ball, or be hit yourself! You have some options of hitting the ball, such as doing a downward smash that doubles the ball speed, or just hitting it straight forward to try to trick your opponent into thinking it'll go somewhere else. Characters fill up a four bar meter everytime they hit the ball, and when full they can use their special attack which can do things like make the ball travel through walls or just eat it and spit it back out! The fun in Lethal League is the simplicity of it, and while simple, it is incredibly fun and satisfying.Music: Music in any game is usually why I keep playing. Lethal League's soundtrack is some of the greatest in indie game music that I've heard. Team Reptile really hit it out of the park with this one, and there was not one single song I disliked in this title. The menu music alone is just phenomenal, and tracks like Ordinary Days and Scream just add to the awesomeness of it. They all loop pretty nicely and sound very well done. The soundtrack in Lethal League will surely not disappoint you at all!Graphics: Lethal League overall looks pretty good for an indie game. The art of the characters is pretty sweet, and so are the backgrounds of each stage. It's also amazing to look at the stages changes the faster you hit the ball, and I feel just makes it way more satisfying to reach insane speeds! The animations feel a bit clunky and weird though, but not something that I really payed much attention to. I will say though, if you want a headache then go ahead and play this game for hours, as it will probably hurt your eyes! Conclusion: I most likely missed some elements and whatnot but I really only wanted to touch on those three topics. That being said, this is a game you MUST play. I recommend it for everyone who loves fighting games and playing with friends. To have the best experience, please do grab some friends and enjoy the hell out of this game! You might not like the 14 dollar price on this game, and that is reasonable due to how simple the game is, but it is worth the money. If you can get some friends, then no doubt you'll be hitting homeruns in no time! Rating: 9/10

												What can only be described as a cross between pong and super smash brothers, this game is now in my top 3 of all time (and I don't just add and subtract games from my list on a whim). I reccomend everyone get this game.It seems simple at first, just hit the ball to your opponent with dodgeball-esqe rules, and the speed of the ball increases over time. 3 controls; hit, jump and bunt. What most people don't realise until they buy the game and play it for 10 minutes, is that this game has so much depth and strategy. You can perform combos to fill up your special meter, you can parry shots with presice timing to throw your opponent off guard, you can bunt the ball whilst travelling one million pixels per frame to surprise other players, you can blahdy blahdy blah. You get the picture.There are only 5 characters, and they seem to all be the same at first, but they all have different angles when hitting the ball and they can interact with the environment in different ways. These may seem suttle, but have a large effect on the gameplay. Each character has a special move unique to them also, and when used correctly, can have a devastating effect on your adversarys.What the hell are you doing. Stop reading this and buy the game so I have more people to play with.If you don't buy it, i'll murder you in your sleep. Tonight.
